{"design_type":"factorial","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"individual participant","is_clustered":false,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Settlement rates for markets where it is feasible","Settlement rates for hard markets (with sum of valuations above 75 but below 100)","Efficiency of markets where it is feasible","Equity of outcomes, measured as proportions of available bargaining surplus assigned to each player"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"arm1","name":"Barg1","role":"experimental","description":"Free bargaining implementation; one-issue bargaining condition.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"arm2","name":"Barg2","role":"experimental","description":"Free bargaining implementation; two-issues bargaining condition.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"arm3","name":"DirODR1","role":"experimental","description":"ODR direct one-shot implementation; one-issue bargaining condition.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"arm4","name":"DirODR2","role":"experimental","description":"ODR direct one-shot implementation; two-issues bargaining condition.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"arm5","name":"SeqODR1","role":"experimental","description":"ODR sequential two-step implementation; one-issue bargaining condition.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"arm6","name":"SeqODR2","role":"experimental","description":"ODR sequential two-step implementation; two-issues bargaining condition.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]}],"factors":[{"factor_id":"f1","name":"Bargaining implementation / mechanism","levels":[{"level_id":"f1l1","name":"Free bargaining (Barg)","description":"Free bargaining mechanism.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"level_id":"f1l2","name":"ODR direct one shot (DirODR)","description":"Online dispute resolution with direct one-shot process.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"level_id":"f1l3","name":"ODR sequential two steps (SeqODR)","description":"Online dispute resolution with sequential two-step process.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]}]},{"factor_id":"f2","name":"Number of issues","levels":[{"level_id":"f2l1","name":"One issue","description":"One-issue bargaining environment.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"level_id":"f2l2","name":"Two issues","description":"Two-issues bargaining environment.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]}]}],"assignment_rules":["Between-subject assignment to a 3x2 design crossing bargaining implementation (Barg, DirODR, SeqODR) with number of issues (one vs two), yielding cells Barg1, Barg2, DirODR1, DirODR2, SeqODR1, SeqODR2.","Participants are organized into groups of 15 within each session; in each round, participants within each group are randomly matched in pairs (re-matched each round)."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Treatments between subjects vary the way barganing is implemented.
 One issue Two issues
Free bargaining (Barg). Barg1 Barg2
ODR direct one shot (DirODR) DirODR1 DirODR2
ODR sequential two steps (SeqODR) SeqODR1 SeqODR2
 We also later add ODRAI treatment, that adjust submitted bids based on predicted overbidding in the ODR1","supports":"Establishes the between-subject treatment structure, the 3 mechanism types, the one-issue vs two-issues dimension, and the named cells; also mentions a later-added ODRAI treatment without full specification."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Treatments.
We have 3x2 between-subject design.
 One issue Two issues
Free bargaining (Barg). Barg1 Barg2
ODR direct one shot (DirODR) DirODR1 DirODR2
ODR sequential two steps (SeqODR) SeqODR1 SeqODR2","supports":"Confirms the design is a 3x2 between-subject factorial and provides the explicit treatment-cell labels."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"There are 30 participants in the experiment in each session, split into two groups of 15 for the whole experiment.
 The experiment consists of 20 rounds. Only one round is payoff relevant. At the beginning of each round, all participants of each group are randomly matched in pairs. Participants know they are matched with a new random participant from the group of 15 every round.","supports":"Provides session/group structure and within-round random matching in pairs (repeated interaction with re-matching)."}],"notes":"Unit of randomization is not explicitly stated; inferred as individual participant from 'between-subject' wording, but registry text does not explicitly describe the random assignment procedure to the 3x2 cells. Additionally, an 'ODRAI' treatment is mentioned as later added, but its level/cell structure and how it integrates into the 3x2 design are not specified, so it is not encoded as an arm/factor level."}

{"design_type":"factorial","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"school","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Hemoglobin concentration","Anemia status (dichotomous indicator)"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Group A1: No incentives + Small block grant (default/reference)","role":"control","description":"Education/information about anemia plus budget support/modest resource transfer and no performance incentives for principals; assigned to the small block grant level.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Group A2: No incentives + Large block grant","role":"experimental","description":"No performance incentives for principals; assigned to the large block grant level.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3"]},{"arm_id":"B1","name":"Group B1: Small anemia reduction incentive + Small block grant","role":"experimental","description":"Principals receive a small performance incentive (12.5 RMB per student reduction in anemia) and are assigned to the small block grant level.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq4"]},{"arm_id":"B2","name":"Group B2: Small anemia reduction incentive + Large block grant","role":"experimental","description":"Principals receive a small performance incentive (12.5 RMB per student reduction in anemia) and are assigned to the large block grant level.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq4"]},{"arm_id":"C1","name":"Group C1: Large anemia reduction incentive + Small block grant","role":"experimental","description":"Principals receive a large performance incentive (125 RMB per student reduction in anemia) and are assigned to the small block grant level.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq5"]},{"arm_id":"C2","name":"Group C2: Large anemia reduction incentive + Large block grant","role":"experimental","description":"Principals receive a large performance incentive (125 RMB per student reduction in anemia) and are assigned to the large block grant level.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq5"]}],"factors":[{"factor_id":"F1","name":"Principal incentive scheme (anemia-reduction performance pay)","levels":[{"level_id":"F1_L0","name":"No incentive (Budget support and information only / Group A)","description":"Principals do not receive any incentive to reduce anemia; they receive only budget support and information.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq3"]},{"level_id":"F1_L1","name":"Small anemia reduction incentive (Group B)","description":"Principals receive 12.5 RMB per student who was anemic at baseline and not anemic at endline (net reduction in number of students anemic).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq4"]},{"level_id":"F1_L2","name":"Large anemia reduction incentive (Group C)","description":"Principals receive 125 RMB per student who was anemic at baseline and not anemic at endline (net reduction in number of students anemic).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq5"]}]},{"factor_id":"F2","name":"Block grant size (black grant/subsidy)","levels":[{"level_id":"F2_L1","name":"Small block grant (Group 1)","description":"0.3 RMB per student per day block grant; orthogonally assigned within incentive groups.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq6"]},{"level_id":"F2_L2","name":"Large block grant (Group 2)","description":"0.7 RMB per student per day block grant; orthogonally assigned within incentive groups.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq6"]}]}],"assignment_rules":["Cluster randomization at the school level: 300 schools were randomly allocated to incentive arms in the full trial; this study uses the subset in Arms 1-3 (Groups A, B, C).","Cross-cutting factorial assignment: incentive arm (5 in full trial; 3 used here) x block-grant size (small vs large) assigned orthogonally, creating experimental cells (10 in full trial; 6 used here).","Stratified randomization: within 25 strata defined by joint quintiles of baseline school-level hemoglobin concentration and combined standardized math and Chinese exam scores, cell assignment was randomized within each stratum."],"design_completeness":"complete","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The trial involved a total of 300 primary schools across Qinghai, Gansu and Shaanxi provinces. The experiment was designed as a cluster randomized trial with 300 schools randomly allocated to one of five treatment arms... Within each of these groups, half were assigned to receive a small subsidy and half a large subsidy.","supports":"Cluster RCT at school level; 5 incentive arms in full trial; cross-cutting small vs large subsidy/grant."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Comparison group: In 65 schools, principals did not receive any incentive to reduce anemia; they received only budget support and information... Large performance incentives: In 65 schools, principals received a larger incentive of 125 yuan... Small performance incentives: In 40 schools, principals received 12.5 Chinese yuan... Across each of the three incentive groups, all schools were randomly assigned to receive small or large black grants...","supports":"Defines the three incentive conditions used in this sub-study and the cross-cutting block grants."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"This part of the study includes only Arm 1, referred to as Group A... Arm 2, referred to as Group C... and Arm 3, referred to as Group B... each of these arms has two orthogonally assigned block-grant arms... a “small” block grant group (Group 1: 85 schools; Group A1: 32 schools; Group B1: 20 schools; Group C1: 33 schools) and a “large” block grant group (Group 2: 85 schools; Group A2: 33 schools; Group B2: 20 schools; Group C2: 32 schools). The reference group is the default policy (education about anemia coupled with a modest resource transfer and no incentives, Group A1).","supports":"Explicit treatment cells (A1,A2,B1,B2,C1,C2), orthogonal block-grant assignment, and identification of the reference/control group A1."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The small incentive group - Group B - was identical to the Group C except that the incentive was 12.5 RMB ($1.95) per student reduction in anemia...","supports":"Small incentive definition (Group B)."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In the large incentive group - Group C - researchers offered school administrators financial incentives... with 125 yuan (RMB) ($19.40) per student reduction in anemia...","supports":"Large incentive definition (Group C)."},{"id":"eq6","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The small block grant group - Group 1 - was 0.3 RMB ($0.05) per student per day... The large block grant - Group 2 - was 0.7 RMB ($0.11) per student per day.","supports":"Defines block grant levels (small vs large)."},{"id":"eq7","source_doc":"registry","quote":"For primary outcomes (hemoglobin concentration and a dichotomous indicator for anemia status)...","supports":"Primary outcomes."},{"id":"eq8","source_doc":"registry","quote":"To improve power, researches used stratified randomization. Using joint quintiles of the baseline distribution of school-level hemoglobin concentration and combined standardized math and Chinese exam scores – yielding 25 strata, researchers randomized cell assignment within each stratum.","supports":"Stratified randomization procedure and strata definition."}],"notes":"Design is a 5x2 cross-cutting factorial in the full trial (5 incentive arms x 2 block-grant sizes = 10 cells). This registry entry focuses on the subset of incentive arms A (none), B (small anemia incentive), C (large anemia incentive), still crossed with block-grant size, yielding 6 cells. Unit of randomization is schools (cluster RCT). Analysis unit is not explicitly stated in the registry text, though outcomes are measured on students; left null per instructions."}

{"design_type":"encouragement","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"preschool","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["School choice","Educational outcomes"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"arm_control","name":"Control group (placebo report card)","role":"control","description":"Parents receive a report card with a flyer highlighting the importance of choosing the right school and a list/map of all secondary schools in the neighborhood (placebo).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq4"]},{"arm_id":"arm_t1","name":"Treatment 1 (SEP info + school list grouped by SEP relevance)","role":"treatment","description":"Provision of a preschool-specific report card including information about SEP and a list/map of secondary schools in the neighborhood; the list is divided into three groups: free for anyone, free for SEP students, and fee-charging schools.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]},{"arm_id":"arm_t2","name":"Treatment 2 (Treatment 1 + school characteristics info)","role":"treatment","description":"Same report card as Treatment 1, plus additional information on school characteristics: test scores, changes in test scores, official tuition cost for SEP and non-SEP parents, school type (public/private), and whether it has preschool and high school.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq4"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Eligible preschools are randomly assigned to one of three arms: control group, treatment 1, or treatment 2.","Randomization is conducted at the preschool level to avoid contamination among parents attending the same preschool and to facilitate implementation via preschool-delivered report cards."],"design_completeness":"complete","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The first treatment is the provision of a report card designed for each preschool that includes information about the SEP and a list with all the secondary schools located in the same neighborhood... the schools' list is divided in three groups \"schools that are free for anyone\" , \"schools that are free for SEP students\" and \"schools that charge fees\" .","supports":"Treatment 1 content"},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The second treatment is the provision of the same report card, but it includes extra information on schools' characteristics: (i) test scores, (ii)a measure of the change in test scores between years, (iii) the official tuition cost for SEP and non SEP parents, (iv) the type of school (i.e. whether it is public or private) and (v) weather it has preschool and high school.","supports":"Treatment 2 content"},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Parents in the control group are also given a report card that includes a flyer highlighting the importance of choosing the right school for their children and a list with all the secondary schools in their neighborhood... The objective of this report card is to act as a placebo.","supports":"Control arm content and placebo role"},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Eligible preschools are randomly assigned to control group, treatment 1 and treatment 2. Randomization is done at the preschool level in order to avoid contamination among treated and control parents attending a same preschool.","supports":"Arms and unit of randomization (preschool-level assignment)"}],"notes":"This is described as an encouragement design; treatments provide information intended to influence take-up/choices related to SEP. The registry text does not explicitly state the level at which outcomes are analyzed, so analysis_unit_canonical is left null."}

{"design_type":"cluster_rct","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"village","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Digital connectivity","Agency","Gender Attitude Index (GAI)","Digital Literacy Transfer Index (DLTI)","Economic empowerment"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"arm1","name":"Treatment (merged: Standard+Extended IVR distance learning)","role":"treatment","description":"15-week IVR-based distance education program (75 pre-recorded audio lessons across literacy, numeracy, and leadership modules) accessed by mothers via toll-free number; originally two treatment variants (Standard and Extended) but merged for this study because interventions were similar.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"arm2","name":"Control group","role":"control","description":"Control group from the original village-level randomization for the IVR intervention study.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq4"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["From an initial list of 140 villages (from 223 ECD-program villages), 90 villages were randomly selected for the IVR study.","The 90 villages were randomly assigned to three groups: Standard treatment, Extended treatment, and Control.","For the current study, the two treatment groups (Standard and Extended) are merged into a single treatment category because mothers in both groups received similar intervention.","Within each village, eligible households were randomly selected for surveying, yielding a baseline sample and final group counts; this household selection is described but the experimental assignment is at village level."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The intervention was a 15-week distance educational intervention included three elementary educational modules – literacy, numeracy, and leadership – divided into 75 audio lessons... Mothers accessed these pre-recorded audio lessons via Interactive Voice Response (IVR) by dialing a toll-free number.","supports":"Intervention content/description for treatment arm(s)."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"We will use original sampling design where 90 villages were randomly selected from a list of 140 villages (out of 223 villages from ECD program) and each of the 90 participating villages randomly distributed into one of three groups, i.e., Standard group, Extended group, and Control group (Wang et al., 2024). However, for this study, we merged these two treatment groups into one as mothers from both treatment groups received similar intervention.","supports":"Unit of randomization (villages), three original arms, and merging of Standard+Extended into one treatment for this study."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Due to budget constraints, 90 villages were selected and then randomized into one of two treatments (i.e., Standard and Extended treatments) and a control group.","supports":"Confirms village-level randomization into Standard, Extended, and control."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The final sample included 596 participants in the Standard treatment group, 586 in the Extended treatment group, and 581 in the control group.","supports":"Confirms existence of Standard, Extended, and control groups in the original design and provides final sample sizes."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The primary outcomes are -, Digital Connectivity... Agency... Gender Attitude Index (GAI)... Digital Literacy Transfer Index (DLTI)... Economic Empowerment...","supports":"Primary outcomes list."},{"id":"eq6","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Within each village, eligible households were randomly selected. This step narrowed the sample down to approximately 1,900 households.","supports":"Household selection within villages (sampling), indicating clustering context but not changing village-level random assignment."}],"notes":"Design classified as a cluster RCT because randomization is explicitly at the village level. Completeness is marked partial because (i) the registry text references an original 3-arm design but states treatments are merged for this study without specifying whether any analyses still distinguish Standard vs Extended; and (ii) the analysis unit for outcomes is not explicitly stated (mother/household/village-level measurement not clearly defined), so analysis_unit_canonical is left null."}

{"design_type":"simple_multiarm","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"individual participant","is_clustered":false,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Increase in step count over baseline at four and eight weeks"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Control group","role":"control","description":"Control group (no Consideration & Connection tasks; still part of three-arm RCT).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Consideration & Connection (C&C)","role":"treatment","description":"Intervention One: Consideration & Connection, designed to increase salience of beliefs about future benefits of physical activity and improve connection to future self.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2","eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A3","name":"Consideration & Connection & Commitment (C&C&C)","role":"treatment","description":"Intervention Two: combines Consideration & Connection with a Commitment task; participants also receive instructions for accessing stickK.com.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2","eq3","eq4"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Equal allocation across three arms.","Randomization occurs after consent and eligibility are established.","Randomization implemented via a Qualtrics computer-generated sequence.","Participants cannot be fully blinded to assignment; researcher also difficult to blind."],"design_completeness":"complete","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Intervention One - Consideration & Connection... Intervention Two - Consideration & Connection & Commitment Group (C&C&C). This intervention combines the Consideration and Connection intervention with the Commitment task.","supports":"Defines the two intervention arms and their content."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"A three (equal) arm randomised control trial comparing the effectiveness of Consideration & Connection (C&C) and Consideration, Connection & Commitment (C&C&C) compared to a control group.","supports":"Confirms three-arm RCT, equal allocation, and the presence of a control group."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Once consent has been given and eligibility has been established participants will be randomised to one of the three groups (Control, Consideration & Connection and Consideration & Connection & Commitment) through a Qualtrics computer generated sequence.","supports":"Lists the three groups explicitly and describes the randomization mechanism and timing."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Those in the Consideration & Connection & Commitment group will also receive instructions about accessing stickK.com (see appendix).","supports":"Additional component specific to the C&C&C arm."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The primary outcome is increase in step count over baseline at four and eight weeks.","supports":"Primary outcome definition."}],"notes":"Unit of randomization inferred as individual participants because eligible participants are randomized online via Qualtrics with no cluster entity described."}

{"design_type":"simple_multiarm","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"urban district (woreda)","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":[],"arms":[{"arm_id":"arm1","name":"Public works (PW)","role":"treatment","description":"Beneficiaries assigned to engage in a public works program.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]},{"arm_id":"arm2","name":"Unconditional direct support transfer (DS)","role":"treatment","description":"Beneficiaries unable to work receive an unconditional direct support transfer.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Randomization is conducted at the urban district (woreda) level."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Program beneficiaries are assigned either to engage in a public works (PW) program or, if they are unable to work, they receive an unconditional direct support transfer (DS).","supports":"Identifies two program assignment categories/arms: PW and DS."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Urban district (woreda) level randomization. See detailed pre-analysis plan.","supports":"Specifies the unit/level of randomization as urban district (woreda)."}],"notes":"Registry text indicates woreda-level randomization (clustered). The mapping from woreda-level assignment to the PW vs DS beneficiary assignment is not fully specified in the entry (e.g., whether PW vs DS is randomized or determined by work ability), and outcomes are not listed (referenced only as in the pre-analysis plan). Hence completeness is marked partial."}

{"design_type":"simple_multiarm","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"individual participant","is_clustered":false,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the original urn (treated group)","Subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the updated urn (treated group)","Ratio between subjective probabilities of prizes 20 and 100 in the original urn (treated group)","Ratio between subjective probabilities of prizes 20 and 100 in the updated urn (treated group)","Ratio between subjective probabilities of prizes 20 and 100 in the urn (control group)","Willingness to accept (WTA) to sell the original lottery (treated group)","Willingness to accept (WTA) to sell the updated lottery (treated group)","Willingness to accept (WTA) to sell the lottery (control group)"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Control treatment","role":"control","description":"Subjects observe 20 draws from an urn with 50 prizes of 100 experimental units and 50 prizes of 20 experimental units; they are explicitly told the urn contains two and only two prizes; they report subjective probabilities and willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the urn.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Surprise treatment — good surprise (E=200)","role":"treatment","description":"Subjects observe 20 draws from the original urn (50 prizes of 100 and 50 prizes of 20), report subjective probabilities and WTA for selling a lottery based on the original urn; then 50 prizes of E are added to form an updated urn and subjects observe a non-random draw featuring prize E; afterwards, subjects again report subjective probabilities and WTA for selling a lottery based on the modified urn. In this sub-treatment, E=200 experimental units.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4","eq5"]},{"arm_id":"A3","name":"Surprise treatment — bad surprise (E=10)","role":"treatment","description":"Same procedure as surprise treatment: initial reports after observing 20 draws from the original urn (50 prizes of 100 and 50 prizes of 20), then addition of 50 prizes of E to create an updated urn, observation of a non-random draw featuring E, and re-elicitation of subjective probabilities and WTA for the modified urn. In this sub-treatment, E=10 experimental units.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4","eq6"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Participants are assigned to one of the two main treatments: control vs surprise.","Within the surprise treatment, participants are assigned to one of two sub-treatments that differ in the value of the added prize E: E=200 (good surprise) vs E=10 (bad surprise)."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"There are two main treatments:","supports":"Existence of multiple treatment conditions (main split)."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In the control treatment: Subjects observe 20 draws from a urn containing 50 prizes of 100 experimental units and 50 prizes of 20 Experimental units and they are explicitly told that they urn contains two and only two prizes.","supports":"Control arm procedure and urn composition."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"They need to report the subjective probabilities of the two prizes and their willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the urn.","supports":"Control arm elicited outcomes/tasks (subjective probabilities; WTA)."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In the surprise treatment: Subjects observe 20 draws from a urn -- that we call \"original urn\" containing 50 prizes of 100 experimental units and 50 prizes of 20 Experimental units. They are asked to report the subjective probabilities of the two prizes and their willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the original urn. Then we add to the original urn -- that we call now \"updated\" urn -- 50 prizes of E experimental units and we ask subjects to observe a new draw from the updated urn. This is a non random draw featuring the prize E. Subjects after observing E, and without other information are asked again to report the subjective probabilities of the two prizes and their willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the modified urn.","supports":"Surprise arm procedure, including original/updated urn sequence, addition of E prizes, non-random draw showing E, and re-elicitation of subjective probabilities and WTA."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In the surprise treatment we further distinguish two different sub-treatments one where the prizes added is E = 200 units - the good surprise treatment;","supports":"Good-surprise sub-treatment definition (E=200)."},{"id":"eq6","source_doc":"registry","quote":"and the other where the prizes added is E = 10 units - the bad surprise treatment.","supports":"Bad-surprise sub-treatment definition (E=10)."},{"id":"eq7","source_doc":"registry","quote":"PRIMARY_OUTCOMES_RAW: (i) The subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the original urn for treated group, (ii) The subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the updated urn for treated group, (iii) The ratio between subjective probabilities of the prizes 20 and 100 respectively in the original urn for the treated group, (iv) The ratio between subjective probabilities of the prizes 20 and 100 respectively in the updated urn for the treated group, (v) The ratio between subjective probabilities of the prizes 20 and 100 respectively in the urn for the control group, (vi) The willingness to accept to sell the original lottery in the treated group, (vii) The willingness to accept to sell the updated lottery in the treated group, (viii) The willingness to accept to sell the lottery in the control group","supports":"Primary outcomes list."},{"id":"eq8","source_doc":"registry","quote":"We plan to run this experiment online by using the Amazon MTurk platform","supports":"Study setting/platform (online MTurk), consistent with individual-level participation."}],"notes":"Design is treated as simple multiarm with three arms (control; surprise-good; surprise-bad) because the registry describes two main treatments with two sub-treatments in the surprise condition. Randomization is implied but not explicitly stated; hence design_completeness is marked partial. No explicit analysis unit is stated."}

{"design_type":"cluster_rct","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"private healthcare facility","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Range of contraceptive methods offered","Overall quality of counseling services","Provider interpersonal skills","Provider overall knowledge","Record-keeping","Loan applications","Current loans","Revenue generation"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Trainings Treatment (offer of comprehensive training package + supportive supervision + complementary services)","role":"treatment","description":"Private health providers/facilities were offered a comprehensive training package (counseling skills, contraceptive technology update, clinical skills, business practices). Providers decided which sessions (if any) their staff would participate in. Supportive supervision and other complementary services were also offered; analysis intended as intent-to-treat of the offer.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2","eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Control (no offer)","role":"control","description":"Private health providers/facilities were not offered any elements of the training package or complementary services.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2","eq3"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Baseline survey conducted prior to randomization; endline survey conducted after intervention among 965 private healthcare facilities.","Stratification step 1: create primary strata by Local Government Area (20 LGAs), ensuring at least four facilities per cell.","Stratification step 2 (if primary cell >16 facilities): create sub-strata by splitting above/below median vignette score, then within each split above/below median business score, yielding final cells within LGA (and similar on scores when sample size permitted).","Within each final cell, randomly assign facilities one-by-one to treatment vs control, producing 484 treatment facilities and 481 control facilities."],"design_completeness":"complete","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Trainings Treatment: Private health providers were offered a comprehensive training package that included sessions on counseling skills, contraceptive technology update, clinical skills, and business practices. The providers then decided which training sessions, if any, their staff would participate in. Supportive supervision services, and other complementary services were also offered.","supports":"Treatment arm description; take-up choice; multi-component offer."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Control: Private health providers were not offered any elements of the training package or complimentary services.","supports":"Control arm description."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"This study used a randomized controlled trial research design, with a baseline survey (prior to randomization) and an endline survey of the 965 private healthcare facilities.
